docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Charles Lewis, the subject of a drug investigation that has also centered on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on three counts of possessing cocaine and seven counts of lying about drug use and possession.

headline.main: Longtime Friend of Capital Mayor Indicted on Federal Drug Charges

docs.snippet: LEAD: Charles Lewis, the subject of a drug investigation that has also centered on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., was indicted today by a Federal grand jury on three counts of possessing cocaine and seven counts of lying about drug use and possession.

byline.original: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Barbara Bush was doing fine yesterday after being treated with a radioactive substance to destroy an overactive thyroid gland, a spokeswoman said.

headline.main: First Lady Undergoes Radiation Treatment for Thyroid Illness

docs.snippet: LEAD: Barbara Bush was doing fine yesterday after being treated with a radioactive substance to destroy an overactive thyroid gland, a spokeswoman said.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: A statistical analysis of all students entering New York City high schools last September shows large percentages of them to be at high risk of dropping out because they were older than average for their grade or had a high absentee rate.

headline.main: New York's Dropouts-to-Be: A Grim Class Portrait

docs.snippet: LEAD: A statistical analysis of all students entering New York City high schools last September shows large percentages of them to be at high risk of dropping out because they were older than average for their grade or had a high absentee rate.

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Protests from older Americans against the surtax for their new extended health coverage have begun to abate, members of Congress say, raising doubts that legislation for changing the program will be considered this year.

headline.main: Protest Over Medicare Surtax Is Said to Ease

docs.snippet: LEAD: Protests from older Americans against the surtax for their new extended health coverage have begun to abate, members of Congress say, raising doubts that legislation for changing the program will be considered this year.

byline.original: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to the New York Times
